alert.note: Alert for Jackson (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued May 26 at 7:07PM EDT until May 27 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... Jackson County in western North Carolina... * Until 200 AM EDT Friday. * At 707 PM EDT, Doppler radar and rain gauges indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across Jackson county. Between 3 and 4 inches of rain have fallen and additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible this evening. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly over localized areas. The Tuckasegee river in Cullowhee is currently at 13.4 feet and rising quickly. Flood stage is 16.0 feet. An area of particular concern is the confluence of the east and west forks of the Tuckasegee river where flooding could develop quickly and adversely affect areas around East Fork Road. Additional significant rises downstream along the Tuckasegee toward Dillsboro are expected over the next several hours. People along the Tuckasegee river and other streams need to be prepared to seek higher ground immediately if flooding begins to occur. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Emergency management reported. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Sylva, Cherokee, Cullowhee, Highlands, Balsam, Webster, Dillsboro, Cashiers, Lake Glenville, B.R. Parkway-Balsam Gap To Black Balsam Area, B.R. Parkway-Smoky Mountains To Balsam Gap, Black Balsam Area, Tuckasegee, Savannah, Whiteside Mountain and Whittier. FLASH FLOOD...OBSERVED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Please heed all messages and evacuation orders from Jackson County emergency management officials. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
